attributes.label: Active Growth Period
attributes.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

attributes.label: Cover Crop Group
attributes.description: Common name for categories of cover crops.

attributes.label: C to N Ratio
attributes.description: C:N ratio is the percentage of organic carbon divided by the percentage of total nitrogen in organic material. Note that the C:N ratio of grasses (warm season annuals) is lower in the vegetative state then in the flowering state.

attributes.label: Drought Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate drought relative to other species.

attributes.label: Duration
attributes.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Early Spring Growth
attributes.description: Speed in the spring at which the cover crop breaks dormancy and grows. No star means that early spring growth is not applicable.

attributes.label: Ease of Establishment
attributes.description:
Degree of difficulty in getting cover crop established.
1 - difficult to establish
5 - very easy to establish

attributes.label: Flooding Frequency Tolerance
attributes.description: Cover crop survival under flooding conditions.

attributes.label: Flood Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.

attributes.label: Flowering Trigger
attributes.description: Details about what triggers flowering: Requires vernalization (spring), Intermediate day (11-13 hrs), Long day (>14 hrs), Based on plant size

attributes.label: Food for Pollinators/Beneficials
attributes.description: Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

attributes.label: Forage Harvest Value
attributes.description: General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).

attributes.label: Good Grazing
attributes.description: General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.

attributes.label: Growing Window
attributes.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

attributes.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
attributes.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

attributes.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
attributes.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

attributes.label: Lasting Residue
attributes.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

attributes.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

attributes.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
attributes.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

attributes.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
attributes.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

attributes.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
attributes.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
attributes.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
attributes.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

attributes.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

attributes.label: Root Depth
attributes.description: Depth to which the cover crop roots. Considers the relative ability of the roots to grow deeper than the previous crop (to reach residual nitrogen).

attributes.label: Seed Price per Pound
attributes.description: Relative cost of seed per pound. One star is least expensive, three stars is most expensive.

attributes.label: Shade Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.

attributes.label: Soil Moisture Use
attributes.description: Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.

attributes.label: Supports Mycorrhizae
attributes.description: Cover crop ability to promote relative activity of mycorrhizal fungi in the rhizosphere.

attributes.label: Suppresses Winter Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.

goals.label: Food for Pollinators/Beneficials
goals.description: Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

goals.label: Forage Harvest Value
goals.description: General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).

goals.label: Good Grazing
goals.description: General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

attributes.label: Biological Nitrogen Fixation
attributes.description: Rates legume cover crops for their ability to fix N by 50% bloom, which will vary by year and proximity to water/altitude.

attributes.label: Cover Crop Group
attributes.description: Common name for categories of cover crops.

attributes.label: C to N Ratio
attributes.description: C:N ratio is the percentage of organic carbon divided by the percentage of total nitrogen in organic material. Note that the C:N ratio of grasses (warm season annuals) is lower in the vegetative state then in the flowering state.

attributes.label: Drought Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate drought relative to other species.

attributes.label: Duration
attributes.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Early Spring Growth
attributes.description: Speed in the spring at which the cover crop breaks dormancy and grows. No star means that early spring growth is not applicable.

attributes.label: Ease of Establishment
attributes.description:
Degree of difficulty in getting cover crop established.
1 - difficult to establish
5 - very easy to establish

attributes.label: Flooding Frequency Tolerance
attributes.description: Cover crop survival under flooding conditions.

attributes.label: Flood Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.

attributes.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
attributes.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

attributes.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
attributes.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

attributes.label: Lasting Residue
attributes.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

attributes.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

attributes.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
attributes.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

attributes.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
attributes.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

attributes.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

attributes.label: Root Depth
attributes.description: Depth to which the cover crop roots. Considers the relative ability of the roots to grow deeper than the previous crop (to reach residual nitrogen).

attributes.label: Shade Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.

attributes.label: Soil Moisture Use
attributes.description: Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.

attributes.label: Flowering Trigger
attributes.description: Details about what triggers flowering: Requires vernalization (spring), Intermediate day (11-13 hrs), Long day (>14 hrs), Based on plant size

attributes.label: Food for Pollinators/Beneficials
attributes.description: Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

attributes.label: Forage Harvest Value
attributes.description: General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).

attributes.label: Good Grazing
attributes.description: General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.

attributes.label: Growing Window
attributes.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

values.value: Frost seeding needs more research for this species due to its slow initial establishment.

attributes.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
attributes.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.description: Relative cost of seed per pound. One star is least expensive, three stars is most expensive.

attributes.label: Shade Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.

attributes.label: Soil Moisture Use
attributes.description: Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.

attributes.label: Supports Mycorrhizae
attributes.description: Cover crop ability to promote relative activity of mycorrhizal fungi in the rhizosphere.

attributes.label: Suppresses Winter Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.

attributes.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

attributes.label: Lasting Residue
attributes.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

attributes.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

attributes.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
attributes.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

attributes.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
attributes.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

attributes.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
attributes.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
attributes.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
attributes.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

attributes.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

attributes.label: Root Depth
attributes.description: Depth to which the cover crop roots. Considers the relative ability of the roots to grow deeper than the previous crop (to reach residual nitrogen).

attributes.label: Seed Price per Pound
attributes.description: Relative cost of seed per pound. One star is least expensive, three stars is most expensive.

attributes.label: Shade Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.

attributes.label: Soil Moisture Use
attributes.description: Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.

attributes.label: Supports Mycorrhizae

attributes.label: Suppresses Winter Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Cover Crop Group
attributes.description: Common name for categories of cover crops.

attributes.label: Drought Tolerance

attributes.label: Early Spring Growth

attributes.label: Ease of Establishment
attributes.description:

attributes.description: Cover crop survival under flooding conditions.

attributes.description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.

attributes.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

attributes.label: Heat Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate heat relative to other species.

attributes.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
attributes.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

attributes.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
attributes.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

attributes.label: Lasting Residue
attributes.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

attributes.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

attributes.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
attributes.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

attributes.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
attributes.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

attributes.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
attributes.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
attributes.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
attributes.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

attributes.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

attributes.label: Root Depth
attributes.description: Depth to which the cover crop roots. Considers the relative ability of the roots to grow deeper than the previous crop (to reach residual nitrogen).

attributes.label: Seed Price per Pound
attributes.description: Relative cost of seed per pound. One star is least expensive, three stars is most expensive.

attributes.label: Shade Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.

attributes.label: Soil Moisture Use
attributes.description: Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.

attributes.label: Supports Mycorrhizae
attributes.description: Cover crop ability to promote relative activity of mycorrhizal fungi in the rhizosphere.

attributes.label: Suppresses Winter Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.

goals.label: Biological Nitrogen Fixation
goals.description: Rates legume cover crops for their ability to fix N by 50% bloom, which will vary by year and proximity to water/altitude.

goals.label: Food for Pollinators/Beneficials
goals.description: Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

goals.label: Forage Harvest Value
goals.description: General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).

goals.label: Good Grazing
goals.description: General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
attributes.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

attributes.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

attributes.label: Root Depth
attributes.description: Depth to which the cover crop roots. Considers the relative ability of the roots to grow deeper than the previous crop (to reach residual nitrogen).

attributes.label: Seed Price per Pound
attributes.description: Relative cost of seed per pound. One star is least expensive, three stars is most expensive.

attributes.label: Shade Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.

attributes.label: Soil Moisture Use
attributes.description: Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.

attributes.label: Supports Mycorrhizae
attributes.description: Cover crop ability to promote relative activity of mycorrhizal fungi in the rhizosphere.

attributes.label: Suppresses Winter Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.

goals.label: Food for Pollinators/Beneficials
goals.description: Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

goals.label: Forage Harvest Value
goals.description: General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).

goals.label: Good Grazing
goals.description: General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.

goals.label: Growing Window
goals.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

goals.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
goals.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

goals.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

goals.label: Lasting Residue
goals.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

goals.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

goals.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
goals.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

goals.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Cover Crop Group
attributes.description: Common name for categories of cover crops.

Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

attributes.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
attributes.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

attributes.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

attributes.label: Root Depth
attributes.description: Depth to which the cover crop roots. Considers the relative ability of the roots to grow deeper than the previous crop (to reach residual nitrogen).

attributes.label: Shade Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.

attributes.label: Soil Moisture Use
attributes.description: Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.

attributes.label: Suppresses Winter Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.

goals.label: Food for Pollinators/Beneficials
goals.description: Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

goals.label: Forage Harvest Value
goals.description: General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).

goals.label: Good Grazing
goals.description: General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.

goals.label: Growing Window
goals.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

goals.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
goals.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

goals.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

goals.label: Lasting Residue
goals.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

goals.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

goals.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
goals.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

goals.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

goals.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Drought Tolerance

attributes.label: Early Spring Growth
attributes.description: Speed in the spring at which the cover crop breaks dormancy and grows. No star means that early spring growth is not applicable.

attributes.label: Ease of Establishment
attributes.description:
Degree of difficulty in getting cover crop established.
1 - difficult to establish
5 - very easy to establish

attributes.label: Flooding Frequency Tolerance
attributes.description: Cover crop survival under flooding conditions.

attributes.label: Flood Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.

attributes.label: Flowering Trigger
attributes.description: Details about what triggers flowering: Requires vernalization (spring), Intermediate day (11-13 hrs), Long day (>14 hrs), Based on plant size

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

goals.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

goals.label: Lasting Residue
goals.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

goals.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

goals.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
goals.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

goals.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

goals.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
goals.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

goals.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Cover Crop Group
attributes.description: Common name for categories of cover crops.

attributes.label: C to N Ratio
attributes.description: C:N ratio is the percentage of organic carbon divided by the percentage of total nitrogen in organic material. Note that the C:N ratio of grasses (warm season annuals) is lower in the vegetative state then in the flowering state.

attributes.label: Drought Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate drought relative to other species.

attributes.label: Duration
attributes.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Early Spring Growth
attributes.description: Speed in the spring at which the cover crop breaks dormancy and grows. No star means that early spring growth is not applicable.

attributes.label: Ease of Establishment
attributes.description:
Degree of difficulty in getting cover crop established.
1 - difficult to establish
5 - very easy to establish

attributes.label: Flooding Frequency Tolerance
attributes.description: Cover crop survival under flooding conditions.

attributes.label: Flood Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.

attributes.label: Flowering Trigger
attributes.description: Details about what triggers flowering: Requires vernalization (spring), Intermediate day (11-13 hrs), Long day (>14 hrs), Based on plant size

attributes.label: Food for Pollinators/Beneficials
attributes.description: Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

attributes.label: Forage Harvest Value
attributes.description: General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).

attributes.label: Good Grazing
attributes.description: General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.

attributes.label: Growing Window
attributes.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

attributes.label: Heat Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate heat relative to other species.

goals.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

goals.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
goals.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

goals.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

goals.label: Lasting Residue
goals.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

goals.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

goals.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
goals.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

goals.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

goals.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
goals.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

goals.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Ease of Establishment
attributes.description:

1 - difficult to establish
5 - very easy to establish

attributes.label: Flooding Frequency Tolerance

attributes.label: Flood Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.

attributes.label: Flowering Trigger

attributes.label: Food for Pollinators/Beneficials

goals.label: Forage Harvest Value
goals.description: General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).

goals.label: Good Grazing
goals.description: General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.

goals.label: Growing Window
goals.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

goals.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
goals.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

goals.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

goals.label: Lasting Residue
goals.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

goals.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

goals.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
goals.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

goals.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

goals.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
goals.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

goals.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Cover Crop Group
attributes.description: Common name for categories of cover crops.

attributes.label: C to N Ratio
attributes.description: C:N ratio is the percentage of organic carbon divided by the percentage of total nitrogen in organic material. Note that the C:N ratio of grasses (warm season annuals) is lower in the vegetative state then in the flowering state.

attributes.label: Drought Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate drought relative to other species.

attributes.label: Duration
attributes.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.label: Early Spring Growth
attributes.description: Speed in the spring at which the cover crop breaks dormancy and grows. No star means that early spring growth is not applicable.

attributes.label: Ease of Establishment
attributes.description:
Degree of difficulty in getting cover crop established.
1 - difficult to establish
5 - very easy to establish

attributes.label: Flooding Frequency Tolerance
attributes.description: Cover crop survival under flooding conditions.

attributes.label: Flood Tolerance
attributes.description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.

attributes.label: Flowering Trigger
attributes.description: Details about what triggers flowering: Requires vernalization (spring), Intermediate day (11-13 hrs), Long day (>14 hrs), Based on plant size

attributes.label: Suppresses Winter Weeds
attributes.description: Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.

goals.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
goals.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

goals.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

goals.label: Lasting Residue
goals.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

goals.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

goals.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
goals.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

goals.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

goals.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
goals.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

goals.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

attributes.description: Common name for categories of cover crops.

attributes.label: Ease of Establishment
attributes.description:

5 - very easy to establish

goals.label: Growing Window
goals.description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.

goals.label: Increase Soil Aggregation
goals.description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.

goals.label: Increase Soil Organic Matter
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.

goals.label: Lasting Residue
goals.description: Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).

goals.label: Living Cover Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.

goals.label: Nitrogen Scavenging
goals.description: Rates a cover crop’s ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. Species with higher C:N ratios will hold N longer than those with lower ratios. The more biomass a cover crop produces, the more N it can take up. Minimizing the time between cover crop termination and soil incorporation and crop establishment will minimize risk of N loss.

goals.label: Penetrates Hard Pan
goals.description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

goals.label: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion
goals.description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

goals.label: Reduces Surface Compaction
goals.description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.

goals.label: Residue Suppresses Weeds
goals.description: Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers weeds. This rating is based on planting as early as possible and terminating as late as possible to get high biomass and high C:N ratio, which will increase the likelihood of success in suppressing weeds.

plantingDates.label: Active Growth Period
plantingDates.description:
Season in which plants have active growth.

Cool season - 40 degrees F - 65 degrees F (For Carlene, September onward)
Warm season - means frost-free, after the first frost (spring through fall in places with freezing weather); 66-95 degrees F (March through July for Carlene)

keyTraits.label: Duration
keyTraits.description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.
